RepresenTaTive molluscs and annelids commonly used for experimenTal and
descripfive embryological sTudies will be supplied. Our inifial laboraTory work
will be concerned wiTh descripTive developmenT of Type forms - or forms which are
readily available aT This Time. IT may be well To remind sTudenTs ThaT cleavage
in These forms is characTerized by parTial roTaTion of The micromeres so-called
spiral cleavage. The spiral paTTern is noT observed wiTh equal ease in all of
The forms, Thus iT is obscure in eggs of Spisula, buT very clear in Those of
Crepidula, eTc. In addifion To The precise paTTern of cleavage The eggs and early
embryos of molluscs and annelids are noTed Tor Their lack of abilify To regulafe.
when blasTomeres are isolaTed, under mosT circumsTances They conTinue To develop
as Though sTill parT of The whole embryo. They exhibiT a mosaicism (or
deTerminaTive cleavage) which has frequenTly been conTrasTed wiTh The regulaTive
(Tendency of parTs To form a whole) behavior of The eggs of oTher forms. Finally
a sTrucTure which is unique To These eggs (and a few relaTed forms) is encounTered
This is The polar lobe, a large mass of non-nucleaTed ooplasm which frequenTly
resembles a blasTomere. The polar lobe forms and reTracTs in wiTh The
firsT few cleavages.
The handling of The eggs and embryos of molluscs and annelids, like Those
of oTher marine forms, requires a reasonable degree of care (see JusT, l939,
Basic MeThods for ExperimenTs on Eggs of Marine Animals). The eggs are sensifive
To adverse condiTions and in order To avoid high TemperaTures, evaporaTion, eTc.,
a sTock baTch of eggs or embryos should be kepT in a covered finger bowl or
sTendor dish on The sea waTer Table. Samples of The embryos may be Taken ouT aT
inTervals for microscopic observafion. Glassware should be Thoroughly washed
To avoid conTaminaTion.
For observing rapidly moving larval sTages iT is necessary To immobilize
Them wiThouT causing excessive harm. Polyvinyl alcohol may be used for This pur-
pose (l parT polyvinyl alcohol To parT sea waTer conTaining The larvae). This
soluTion is very viscous and slows down larval movemenT wiThouT apparanT damage.
A l:2 soluTion of ChlorobuTanol (MS 222) may also be used.
EMBRYOLOGY oF MoLLuscA
?pisula sglidjssima (Pelecypod)
l. ObTaining Eggs. Remove hinge of The clam, breaking The ovary and forcing The
eggs To exude inTo a beaker of TilTered sea waTer. DecanT 4 Times in The firsT
half hour, leave The heavier more maTure eggs on The boTTom of The beaker.
Add Two drops of a sperm suspension (one drop of dry sperm in IO ml. sea waTer) To
eggs conTained in 40-50 ml. of waTer in The beaker. LimiT egg concenTraTion so
ThaT There are no more Than 20-26 in a lower power field since They are very
suscepTible To overcrowding. Dry ovaries and TesTes may be kepT overnighT in a
refrigeraTor. Washed eggs may be kepT for 4 66 6 hours.
2. The unferTili;ed egg; ObTain a sample of unferTilized eggs in a sTendor dish
and Transfer To~a depression slide for sTudy. when shed, The eggs are irregular
in shape due To pressure wlThin The ovary, buT They become spherical on sTanding.
They are small (56 micra) and The cenTer is almosT compleTely filled by The
enormous germinaL yesicle wiTh iTs prominenT nucleolus. Unless eggs are
inseminafed They will mainTain This appearance for many hours. The eggs are
ferTilizable unTil The germinal vesicle breaks down, alThough The capaciTy for
normal ferTilizaTion and developmenT is impaired wiTh long sfanding.
